Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Expectation2: Ensure compliance with safety and regulatory standards
Situation2: An external inspector has raised immediate concerns that could halt operations unless issues are resolved
Story: I stared at my phone, rereading the group chat messages from my family. My sister’s excitement about the holiday trip was contagious, and Mom’s reminders about how much it meant to everyone tugged at me. I knew how rare it was for all of us to be together, and I could almost hear Dad’s voice, “Family comes first.” But as I glanced at my laptop, the email from the external inspector glared back at me. The safety concerns were serious—if I didn’t address them immediately, our operations could be shut down, and the team was counting on me to ensure everything was up to code. My manager’s words echoed in my mind: “We can’t afford any slip-ups. You’re the lead on this.” I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in, my family’s expectations pulling me one way, my professional responsibility anchoring me the other. My heart raced as I tried to figure out how I could possibly be in two places at once, knowing that no matter what I chose, I’d be letting someone down.
